context: Antibiotics are screened for any <a5_0><a10_0><b18_0>negative effects<b18_0/><a5_0/> on humans or other mammals<a10_0/> before approval for <a6_0>clinical use<a6_0/>, and are usually considered safe and most are well tolerated. However, some antibiotics have been associated with a range of adverse side effects. Side-effects range from mild to very serious depending on the antibiotics used, the <a7_0>microbial organisms<a7_0/> targeted, and the individual patient. Side effects may reflect the pharmacological or toxicological properties of the antibiotic or may involve hypersensitivity reactions or anaphylaxis. Safety profiles of newer drugs are often not as well established as for those that have a long history of use. <a8_0>Adverse effects<a8_0/> range from <a0_0><a11_0><b15_0>fever and nausea<b15_0/><a0_0/> to major allergic reactions, including photodermatitis and anaphylaxis<a11_0/>. Common side-effects include <a12_0>diarrhea<a12_0/>, resulting from <a1_0><b16_0>disruption of the species composition in the intestinal flora<a1_0/>,<b16_0/> resulting, for example, in overgrowth of pathogenic bacteria, such as Clostridium difficile. Antibacterials can also affect the vaginal flora, and may lead to <a13_0>overgrowth of <a2_0>yeast<a13_0/><a2_0/> species of the genus Candida in the vulvo-vaginal area. <a14_0>Additional side-effects<a14_0/> can result from interaction with other drugs, such as elevated risk of tendon damage from administration of <a3_0><b17_0>a quinolone antibiotic with a systemic corticosteroid<b17_0/><a3_0/>. Some scientists have hypothesized that the indiscriminate use of antibiotics <a4_0>alter the <a9_0>host microbiota<a9_0/><a4_0/> and this has been associated with chronic disease.
